sub_topic: Calculation of Gibbs free energy change for a chemical reaction
message_1:
Calculate the Gibbs free energy change at standard conditions for the combustion of propane:

C3H8(g) + 5O2(g) → 3CO2(g) + 4H2O(l) 

Given the standard enthalpy of formation data: 
ΔH°f(CO2(g)) = -393.5 kJ/mol 
ΔH°f(H2O(l)) = -285.8 kJ/mol 
ΔH°f(C3H8(g)) = -103.85 kJ/mol 
and the standard entropy data: 
S°(CO2(g)) = 213.6 J/(mol•K) 
S°(H2O(l)) = 69.9 J/(mol•K) 
S°(C3H8(g)) = 269.9 J/(mol•K)
message_2:
To calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°) at standard conditions for the combustion of propane, we first need to find the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) and the standard entropy change (ΔS°) for the reaction.

1. Calculate the standard enthalpy change (ΔH°) for the reaction:
ΔH° = [Σ ΔH°f(products)] - [Σ ΔH°f(reactants)]
ΔH° = [3ΔH°f(CO2(g)) + 4ΔH°f(H2O(l))] - [ΔH°f(C3H8(g)) + 5ΔH°f(O2(g))]

Since the standard enthalpy of formation for O2(g) is zero (it's an element in its standard state), we can simplify the equation:

ΔH° = [3(-393.5) + 4(-285.8)] - [-103.85]
ΔH° = (-1180.5 - 1143.2) + 103.85
ΔH° = -2219.85 kJ/mol

2. Calculate the standard entropy change (ΔS°) for the reaction:
ΔS° = [Σ S°(products)] - [Σ S°(reactants)]
ΔS° = [3S°(CO2(g)) + 4S°(H2O(l))] - [S°(C3H8(g)) + 5S°(O2(g))]

The standard entropy for O2(g) is 205.0 J/(mol•K). Now we can plug in the values:

ΔS° = [3(213.6) + 4(69.9)] - [269.9 + 5(205.0)]
ΔS° = (640.8 + 279.6) - (269.9 + 1025.0)
ΔS° = 920.4 - 1294.9
ΔS° = -374.5 J/(mol•K)

3. Calculate the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG°) at standard conditions (298 K):
ΔG° = ΔH° - TΔS°
ΔG° = -2219.85 kJ/mol - (298 K × -0.3745 kJ/(mol•K))

Note that we need to convert ΔS° to kJ/(mol•K) by dividing by 1000:

ΔG° = -2219.85 kJ/mol - (298 K × -0.0003745 kJ/(mol•K))
ΔG° = -2219.85 kJ/mol + 111.621 kJ/mol
ΔG° = -2108.229 kJ/mol

So, the Gibbs free energy change at standard conditions for the combustion of propane is -2108.229 kJ/mol.
